'''Kuali''' is a higher education software development company based in [[Salt Lake City]], [[Utah]]. The company develops [[Open-source software|open-source]] administration software for universities and colleges in collaboration with higher education partner institutions. As of 2014, about 59 institutions were involved in the development of various Kuali products.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/news/2014/10/02/educause-conference-kuali-leaders-attempt-assure-college-leaders-about-shifts|title=At Educause conference, Kuali leaders attempt to assure college leaders about shifts|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.edsurge.com/news/2018-02-13-almost-four-years-after-creating-a-for-profit-kuali-raises-10m-from-owl-ventures|title=After Almost 4 Years as a For-Profit, Kuali Raises $10M from Owl Ventures - EdSurge News|date=2018-02-13|work=EdSurge|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/blogs/digital-tweed/kuali-goes-profits|title=Kuali Goes For Profits {{!}} Inside Higher Ed|website=www.insidehighered.com|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
The Kuali community consists of universities and colleges cooperating to build open-source, scalable, and service driven tools. Kuali and its community have worked together to build many different tools including Kuali Open Library Environment (OLE), the Kuali Financial System, Kuali Rice, Kuali Research, and Kuali Coeus.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=hcqUAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA82&dq=Kuali&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjF-tyT6JDaAhXFPY8KHbFaBkMQ6AEISzAH#v=onepage&q=Kuali&f=false|title=Library Automation: Core Concepts and Practical Systems Analysis, 3rd Edition: Core Concepts and Practical Systems Analysis|last=Bilal|first=Dania|date=2014-03-26|publisher=ABC-CLIO|isbn=9781591589235|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://kc.mit.edu/about-kuali-coeus|title=About Kuali Coeus {{!}} MIT Kuali Coeus|website=kc.mit.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siue.edu/funding/external-funding/kuali-research.shtml|title=Kuali Research|website=www.siue.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
== History == The Kuali community began in 2004.The organization was established to take on the “Kuali Project,” a project aimed at developing a community sourced financial system. The group was founded by the [[University of Hawaii]], [[Indiana University]], rSmart and The National Association of College and University Business Officers (NACUBO) with an initial grant of $ 2.5 million from [[Andrew W. Mellon Foundation]] and funding by the founding members.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=52hZKv6olzEC&pg=PA249&dq=Kuali&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiv5PrG5pDaAhUFuY8KHexOBdAQ6AEIJDAA#v=onepage&q=Kuali&f=false|title=International Comparisons of Information Communication Technologies: Advancing Applications: Advancing Applications|last=B|first=Tan, Felix|date=2011-12-31|publisher=IGI Global|isbn=9781613504819|language=en}}</ref>
In 2005, the Kuali community organized a more formal non-profit organization, the Kuali Foundation. The new organization was created “for higher education, by higher education,” and its member dues-paying institutions rose to 74 by 2014.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://www.chronicle.com/article/Open-Source-Software-for/146205|title=Open-Source Software for College Administrators Reaches ‘Tipping Point’ After 10 Years|date=2014-04-28|work=The Chronicle of Higher Education|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
In August 2014, the Kuali Foundation announced the launch of its for-profit commercial entity.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.academica.ca/top-ten/kuali-foundation-drops-non-profit-status|title=Kuali Foundation drops non-profit status {{!}} Academica Group - Research and Consulting for Higher Education|website=www.academica.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> The company’s existing software remained free and open-source and the Kuali Foundation would still exist, but the company would launch new services.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mfeldstein.com/kuali-profit-change-indicator-bigger-issues/|title=Kuali For-Profit: Change is an indicator of bigger issues|date=2014-08-25|work=e-Literate|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
In February 2018, Kuali raised $ 10 million from Owl Ventures. The funds secured will be used to hire more employees, build more features in the Kuali Student Curriculum Management System (KSCM), and create more modules in Kuali Research.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.insidehighered.com/quicktakes/2018/02/14/kuali-raises-10-million|title=Kuali Raises $10 Million {{!}} Inside Higher Ed|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://mfeldstein.com/kuali-student-sunsetting-40-million-project-moving-kualico/|title=Kuali Student Sunsetting $40 million project, moving to KualiCo|date=2014-10-09|work=e-Literate|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Products ==
=== Kuali Student === Kuali Student is a student information system that can be used for curriculum management, academic planning, management of personal identity, management of student information and other student services.<ref name=":2" /> Curriculum Management, a Kuali Student module, enables faculty to plan and develop courses and programs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://campustechnology.com/articles/2013/12/12/u-washington-deploys-kuali-open-source-student-information-system.aspx|title=U Washington To Deploy Kuali Open Source Student Information System -|last=Namahoe|first=By Kanoe|last2=12/12/13|website=Campus Technology|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
=== Kuali Research === Kuali Research is an enterprise software system that addresses the full sponsored projects life cycle.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vpr.colostate.edu/kr/|title=Kuali Research – Kuali Research at Colorado State University|website=vpr.colostate.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> The software handles administrative processes for pre- and post-award tasks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vpr.colostate.edu/kr/2016/09/18/breaking-down-the-applications-in-kuali-coeus/|title=Breaking Down the Applications in Kuali Research – Kuali Research|website=vpr.colostate.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref> It was created by academic researchers, in keeping with Kuali’s “by and for higher education” slogan.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://rgs.usu.edu/kuali/|title=Welcome to Kuali Research!|work=Kuali|access-date=2018-04-13|language=en-US}}</ref> It can be used by OPR staffs, investigators and others for collaboration of research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.siue.edu/funding/external-funding/kuali-research.shtml|title=Kuali Research|website=www.siue.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
The application was created through the collaborative effort of multiple higher education institutions, including the University of Maryland, Indiana University, University of Toronto, Boston College, University of Washington and North-West University.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://campustechnology.com/articles/2013/12/12/u-washington-deploys-kuali-open-source-student-information-system.aspx|title=U Washington To Deploy Kuali Open Source Student Information System -|last=Namahoe|first=By Kanoe|last2=12/12/13|website=Campus Technology|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
=== Kuali Financial System === KFS is software that can be used for business transactions, budget management, purchasing, payments and reimbursement, capital asset management, labor distribution and many other financial functions. KFS improves accountability by providing an online history of all transactions and related administrative services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://guide.uconn.edu/financial-processes/financial-records-system-frs/|title=Kuali Financial System (KFS) {{!}} Faculty and Staff Resource Guide|website=guide.uconn.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://itservices.usc.edu/adminsystems/kfs/|title=Kuali Financial System {{!}} IT Services {{!}} USC|website=itservices.usc.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
=== Kuali Ready === Kuali Ready is a cloud-based software that provides a framework for Business Continuity Planning (BCP). BCP software can help higher ed institutions mitigate and/or recover from unexpected disruptions until normal business operations can be restored. Kuali Ready was originally developed by the University of California Berkeley.<ref>https://www.csudh.edu/Assets/csudh-sites/rm-ehos/docs/business-continuity/guide-to-business-continuity-planning-on-campus.pdf</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ohio.edu/riskandsafety/continuity/|title=Business Continuity Planning|website=www.ohio.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-04-13}}</ref>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Companies based in Utah]] [[Category:Free educational software]] [[Category:Learning management systems]]

{{Infobox dot-com company | name = Lemon, Inc. | logo = Lemon Wallet.png | logo_size = 250px | screenshot = | caption = | locations = 1 (in [[Argentina]]) | founder = [[Wences Casares]] | chairman = | chairperson = | president = | CEO = [[Wences Casares]] | MD = | GM = | industry = [[Mobile payment|Mobile wallet]] | products = | services = Freemium Lemon Wallet app; Subscription-based Lemon Wallet app | revenue = | url = {{URL|www.lemon.com}} | ipv6 = | alexa = | advertising = No | registration = Required | language = [[English language|English]] | footnotes = | company_type = | traded_as = | foundation = {{Start date|2011|07}} | location_city = [[Palo Alto]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States]] | area_served = United States | company_slogan = | programming_language = | website_type = [[Online service]] | num_users = | launch_date = {{Start date|2012|06}} | current_status = Disabled | intl = }}
'''Lemon Wallet''' was a [[Cloud-based integration|cloud-based]] [[digital wallet]] that allowed users to store digital copies of [[credit cards]], [[debit cards]], reward cards, as well as [[identification cards|identification]], and other card information. The service was released in July 2011 and the company is based in [[Palo Alto]], [[California]], [[United States]].<ref name="The Next Web">{{cite web | url=https://thenextweb.com/apps/2011/10/05/store-your-receipts-online-and-keep-track-of-your-budget-with-lemon/ | title=Store your receipts online and keep track of your budget with Lemon | publisher=''The Next Web'' | date=October 5, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Messieh, Nancy}}</ref><ref name="Mashable 1">{{cite web | url=http://mashable.com/2011/10/18/lemon/ | title=Lemon Makes Lemonade Out of Your Electronic & Paper Receipts | publisher=''[[Mashable]]'' | date=October 19, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Van Grove, Jennifer}}</ref><ref name="CNN 1">{{cite web | url=http://tech.fortune.cnn.com/2011/11/16/receipts-startups/ | title=Receipts are a nightmare. These startups want to help you wake up | publisher=''[[CNN]]'' | work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] | date=November 16, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Konrad, Alex}}</ref> [[Wences Casares]] was the company's [[chief executive officer|CEO]].{{citation needed|date=June 2015}}
The Lemon Network platform, launched in July 2013, connected payment information from Lemon Wallet directly to a merchant for payment processing.<ref name="The Next Web"/><ref name="CNN 1"/><ref name="CBS">{{cite web | url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-505143_162-57333467/lemon-iphone-app-keeps-track-of-your-receipts-for-free/ | title=Lemon iPhone app keeps track of your receipts for free | publisher=''[[CBS News]]'' | date=November 30, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Johnson, Dave}}</ref><ref name="Fox News">{{cite web | url=http://www.foxnews.com/tech/2012/01/06/post-holiday-apps-turn-your-unwanted-gifts-into-treasure/ | title=Turn Your Unwanted Holiday Gifts Into Treasure | publisher=''[[Fox News]]'' | date=January 6, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013}}</ref>
In December 2013, Lemon Wallet was acquired by [[LifeLock]].<ref name="TechCrunch">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/12/12/lifelock-acquires-mobile-wallet-platform-lemon-for-42-6-million/ | title=LifeLock Acquires Mobile Wallet Platform Lemon For $42.6 Million, Launches LifeLock Wallet }}</ref>
== Services and products ==
Lemon used [[Optical character recognition|OCR technology]] to store and organize users' information from various cards ([[Identity document|IDs]], [[health insurance]], [[credit card|credit]], [[debit card|debit]], rewards, etc.) and [[receipts]].<ref name="Tuaw">{{cite web | url=http://www.tuaw.com/2013/05/31/friday-favorite-lemon-wallet/ | title=Friday Favorite: Lemon Wallet | publisher=''Tuaw'' | date=May 31, 2013 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Sande, Steven}}</ref><ref name="USA Today">{{cite web | url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/tech/columnist/kimkomando/story/2011-10-21/komando-track-personal-expenses/50841528/1 | title=Track expenses the easy way | publisher=''[[USA Today]]'' | date=October 21, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Komando, Kim}}</ref><ref name=slots>{{cite web|title=Online Slots 2015|url=http://slotsonlinecanada.com|publisher=slotsonlinecanda|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref><ref name="Fast Company">{{cite web | url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1840080/lemon-takes-aim-digitizing-your-bulging-paper-stuffed-back-crippling-wallet | title=Lemon takes aim at digitizing your (Bulging, Paper-stuffed, Back-crippling) wallet | publisher=''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'' | date=June 12, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Eaton, Kit}}</ref><ref name="PC Mag">{{cite web | url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2408249,00.asp | title=Lemon Wallet (for iPhone) | publisher=''[[PC Magazine]]'' | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Duffy, Jill}}</ref> An upgraded version allowed users to monitor bank accounts and includes expanded security features such credit card balance monitoring, alerts for questionable charges, card expiration reminders, and the ability to cancel and restore cards.<ref name="Tuaw"/><ref name="iMore">{{cite web | url=http://www.imore.com/lemon-wallet-iphone-review-create-passbook-cards-your-entire-wallet-and-much-more | title=Lemon Wallet for iPhone review: Create Passbook cards for your entire wallet and much more | publisher=''iMore'' | date=May 13, 2013 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Kazmucha, Allyson}}</ref> Lemon also allowed users to store receipt data.<ref name="USA Today"/><ref name="CNet">{{cite web | url=http://howto.cnet.com/8301-11310_39-57376917-285/three-ways-your-smartphone-can-lighten-up-a-heavy-wallet/ | title=Three ways your smartphone can lighten up a heavy wallet | publisher=''[[CNET]]'' | date=February 14, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Vaknin, Sharon}}</ref><ref name="Appstorm">{{cite web | url=http://web.appstorm.net/reviews/finances-reviews/lemon-an-easy-way-to-track-your-expenses/ | title=Lemon: An Easy Way to Track Your Expenses | publisher=''Appstorm'' | date=December 13, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Takenouchi, Shaun}}</ref> The service also organized expense reports (using receipt data), which could be accessed from the web application or mobile device.<ref name="The Next Web"/><ref name="CBS"/><ref name="LifeHacker">{{cite web | url=http://lifehacker.com/5846831/lemon-is-an-easy-to-use-and-free-receipt-tracking-tool-for-mobile-phones-and-online | title=Lemon Is an Easy to Use and Free Receipt Tracking Tool for Mobile Phones and Browsers | publisher=''Lifehacker'' | date=October 5, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Klosowski, Thorin}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch 3">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/12/mobile-money-management-app-lemon-launches-digital-wallet-closes-8-million-series-a/ | title=Mobile Money Management App Lemon Launches Digital Wallet, Closes $8 Million Series A | publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=June 12, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Perez, Sarah}}</ref> This data could be used to submitting expense reports.<ref name="Appstorm"/><ref name="NY Times 1">{{cite web | url=http://bucks.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/25/lemon-turns-paper-receipts-into-digital-versions/?_r=0 | title=Lemon Makes Digital Copies of Paper Receipts | publisher=''[[The New York Times]]'' | date=October 25, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Carnns, Ann}}</ref><ref name="TechCrunch 1">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/10/13/backed-by-10m-in-funding-lemon-com-lets-you-store-organize-your-receipts-in-the-cloud/ | title=Backed By $10M In Funding, Lemon.com Lets You Store, Organize Your Receipts In The Cloud | publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=October 13, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Wauters, Robin}}</ref> A [[freemium]] version of the service was available, as well as a paid subscription.<ref name="CNN 1"/><ref name="Appstorm"/><ref name="Appvita">{{cite web | url=http://www.appvita.com/2011/12/02/lemon-organized-receipts-for-easier-recordkeeping/ | title=Get an interface lift from Dotvita Lemon – Organized Receipts for Easier Recordkeeping | publisher=''Appvita'' | date=December 2, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Miles, Stephanie}}</ref> The Lemon application was compatible with [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], and [[Windows Phone]] devices.<ref name="The Next Web"/><ref name="Mashable 1"/><ref name="USA Today"/><ref name="CNet"/><ref name="US News">{{cite web | url=http://money.usnews.com/money/personal-finance/articles/2012/01/30/5-apps-for-organizing-your-expenses-at-tax-time | title=5 Apps for Organizing Your Expenses at Tax Time | publisher=''[[U.S. News & World Report]]'' | date=January 30, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Johnston, Susan}}</ref><ref name="GigaOM">{{cite web | url=http://gigaom.com/2012/02/24/receipt-tracker-lemon-hits-1-million-users-adds-mint-like-features/ | title=Receipt tracker Lemon hits 1 million users, adds Mint-like features | publisher=''[[GigaOM]]'' | date=February 24, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Kim, Ryan}}</ref>
== History and product developments ==
The company released the beta version of the service as an expense tracking and management service in July 2011.<ref name="The Next Web"/><ref name="Mashable 1"/><ref name="LifeHacker"/> It soft-launched at the [[TechCrunch]] Disrupt conference's startup alley in September 2011, and officially launched in October 2011.<ref name="TechCrunch 1"/><ref name="Venture Beat">{{cite web | url=https://venturebeat.com/2011/09/13/lemon-com-receipt-tracking/ | title=Tired of keeping track of receipts? Lemon.com can help | publisher=''[[VentureBeat]]'' | date=September 13, 2011 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Hardawar, Devindra}}</ref> In February 2012, the company announced it had reached one million users.<ref name="GigaOM"/>
Lemon received $8 million in a funding round led by Maveron in May 2012.<ref name="Fast Company"/><ref name="TechCrunch 3"/><ref name="Wall Street 1">{{cite web | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2012/06/12/lemon-to-squeeze-more-juice-from-e-wallets/ | title=Lemon Aims to Squeeze More Juice from E-Wallets | publisher=''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' | date=June 12, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Kolodny, Lora}}</ref> Other investors in the Series A round included [[Lightspeed Venture Partners]], [[Draper Fisher Jurvetson]], CampVentures, and [[Social+Capital Partnership]].<ref name="Fast Company"/><ref name="TechCrunch 3"/> The round followed Lemon's release of the Lemon Wallet app, a service designed to store credit, debit, health insurance, and ID card information using the same photo system the company utilized for expense management.<ref name="Fast Company"/><ref name="TechCrunch 3"/><ref name="Wall Street 1"/> The extended capabilities allowed users to backup everything in their wallet using Lemon's cloud-based, [[Personal identification number|PIN protected]] database.<ref name="PC Mag"/><ref name="TechCrunch 3"/> The app's security features include a 256-bit encryption as well as the ability for the user to remote-wipe sensitive information if the mobile device is lost or stolen.<ref name="Fast Company"/><ref name="PC Mag"/><ref name="iMore"/>
Beginning in September 2012, Lemon customers could access cards stored in their Lemon account through [[Apple, Inc.|Apple's]] Passbook service.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.paymentssource.com/news/square-lemon-add-support-for-apples-passbook-wallet-3012591-1.html | title=Square, Lemon Add Support for Apple's Passbook Wallet | publisher=''PaymentsSource'' | date=December 10, 2012 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Wolfe, Daniel}}</ref>
In May 2013, Lemon announced an upgraded expense reporting tool. The enhancement to the Lemon Wallet granted users the ability to have their receipts and e-receipts processed through lemon.com and saved as a [[Portable Document Format|PDF copy]] and a [[Comma-separated values|CSV]] or [[Microsoft Excel file format#File formats|XLS]] format copy to be compatible with other expense software. Lemon CEO Wences Casares has reported that as of May 2013, the digital wallet service is capturing and storing approximately 1,000 new cards every hour.<ref name="TechCrunch 2">{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/30/lemons-mobile-wallet-gets-more-useful-with-new-expense-reporting-service-support-for-transactions-is-next/ | title=Lemon's Mobile Wallet Gets More Useful With New Expense Reporting Service; Support For Transactions Is Next | publisher=''[[TechCrunch]]'' | date=May 30, 2013 | accessdate=August 21, 2013 | author=Perez, Sarah}}</ref>
On December 12, 2013, it was announced that [[LifeLock, Inc.]], a provider of identity theft protection services, acquired Lemon.<ref>[http://www.lifelock.com/pr/2013/12/12/lifelock-acquires-mobile-wallet-innovator-lemon/ LifeLock | Press Room | Leading Identity Theft Protection Company LifeLock Acquires Mobile Wallet Innovator Lemon, Inc<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
On May 16, 2014, LifeLock, Inc. announced that it had temporarily disabled the mobile application due to a security flaw.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.lifelockunlocked.com/lifelock-news/an-important-update-about-lifelock-wallet/|title = An Important Update About LifeLock Wallet|date = May 16, 2014|accessdate = May 24, 2014|website = LifeLockUnlocked|publisher = LifeLock, Inc.|last = Davis|first = Todd}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|30em}}

revision.text:
{{for|the Zoroastian expert at Cambridge University|Mary Boyce}} {{BLP primary sources|date=October 2014}} '''Mary Cunningham Boyce''' is the Dean of the [[Columbia School of Engineering and Applied Science|Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science]] at [[Columbia University]]. She is the Morris A. and Alma Schapiro Professor. She is the fifteenth dean of the school and the first female to hold the position. Her term began on July 1, 2013.<ref>[http://engineering.columbia.edu/dean-mary-c-boyce Mary Boyce], MIT</ref><ref>"[http://news.mit.edu/2013/boyce-appointed-columbia-engineering-dean-0326 Mary Boyce to lead Columbia University’s engineering school]," MIT News, March 26, 2013</ref><ref>"[http://columbiaspectator.com/opinion/2013/03/27/welcoming-dean-boyce Welcoming Dean Boyce]," Columbia Spectator, March 27, 2013.</ref><ref>Robert McCaughey , "A Lever Long Enough: A History of Columbia's School of Engineering and Applied Science Since 1864," Columbia University Press, June 10, 2014, [https://books.google.com/books?id=gsnbAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA275&lpg=PA275&dq=%22Mary+Cunningham+Boyce%22&source=bl&ots=Aq8CHmfzSu&sig=OPa2b0xthekiPWB3lUAmuVB1krA&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGlN-xnM7MAhXCbR4KHWRmDEg4FBDoAQgbMAA#v=onepage&q=%22Mary%20Cunningham%20Boyce%22&f=false p. 275]</ref>
As dean, Boyce leads the education and research mission of Columbia Engineering, which has more than 220 faculty, 1600 undergraduate students and 2600 graduate students.
A strong advocate of interdisciplinary research and translation of innovation to impact, she has increased faculty in cross-cutting fields, and recently launched a new vision for the school, Columbia Engineering for Humanity. This vision reflects the over 150 year history of Columbia Engineering while also articulating the impact of engineering on the lives of people around the world - our impact on a sustainable, a healthy, a secure, a connected, and a creative humanity.
Her own research focuses on materials and mechanics, particularly in the areas of multi-scale mechanics of polymers and soft composites, both those that are man-made and those formed naturally.
==Background==
Boyce earned her B.S. degree in Engineering Science and Mechanics at Virginia Tech and her M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in Mechanical Engineering at MIT. Prior to joining Columbia University, Boyce spent twenty-five years as a faculty member at [[MIT]]. During her last years at MIT, she was the Head of Department for Mechanical Engineering and the Ford Professor of Engineering.
Boyce's research interests include the multi-scale mechanics of polymers, soft composites and soft tissues. Her research has been in theory, computation and experimental elements of the nonlinear, finite deformation, elastic and inelastic, time-dependent behavior of polymeric-based materials. Her leadership in the field of the mechanics of materials has expanded the understanding of interplay between micro-geometry and the inherent physical behavior of a material, which has led to innovative hybrid material designs, as well as materials structures that transform or morph into a different structure. Models and results from Professor Boyce's group have the potential to influence a range of industrial and academic fields from polymer processing to composite material design, tire mechanics, biological cells and tissues. The author of more than 170 publications with her group, she is also the holder of five US patents. Boyce has mentored over 25 PhD students and numerous postdoctoral researchers. Her PhD students and postdoctoral researchers have bone onto faculty positions across the country and the world, as well as to national laboratories, industries and consulting careers.
Boyce has been widely recognized for her scholarly achievements, including election as a fellow of the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]], the American Academy of Mechanics, the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]], and the [[National Academy of Engineering]].<ref>[https://www.nae.edu/56119.aspx Mary Boyce's Webpage at the National Academy of Engineering]</ref> She also has been honored for her teaching at MIT, where she was named a MacVicar Faculty Fellow and received the Joseph Henry Keenan Innovation in Undergraduate Education Award.
Boyce earned her [[B.S.]] degree in Engineering Science and Mechanics from Virginia Tech and her [[Master of Science|S.M.]] and [[Ph.D.]] degrees in [[Mechanical Engineering]] from [[MIT]].

NanoAndMore USA Inc., USA | homepage = {{URL|www.nanoandmore.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''NanoAndMore'''{{Cite journal | last1 = Stefanov | first1 = Y. | last2 = Ruland | first2 = T. | last3 = Schwalke | first3 = U. | title = Electrical AFM Measurements for Evaluation of Nitride Erosion in Shallow Trench Isolation Chemical Mechanical Planarization | journal = MRS Proceedings | volume = 838 | year = 2011 | doi = 10.1557/PROC-838-O10.5}} is a distributor for [[AFM probe|AFM cantilevers]] from [[NanoWorld]], [[Nanosensors (company)|Nanosensors]], BudgetSensors and nanotools, calibration standards and other products for [[nanotechnology]]. == History == NanoAndMore was founded in Germany in 2002 and started operating in the USA in 2005. In 2005, NanoWorld Holding AG from [[Schaffhausen]], Switzerland, acquired and integrated NanoAndMore into the NanoWorld group composed of [[Nanotechnology]] companies. The world market leader in [[AFM probe]]s, [[NanoWorld]] has appointed NanoAndMore as official distributor for [[NanoWorld]] and [[Nanosensors (company)|Nanosensors]] products.{{cite web |url= http://www.nanotech-now.com/news.cgi?story_id=12616 |title= NanoWorld AG appoints NanoAndMore USA Corp. |author= www.nanotech-now.com |date= 1 November 2005 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=17 January 2012}} NanoAndMore is operating from a location in [[Wetzlar]], Germany - serving the European market - and from [[Lady's Island (South Carolina)]], United States{{cite web |url= http://www.savannahbusinessjournal.com/news/67-lowcountry-news/1538-oct-12-beauforts-nanoandmore-one-of-three-national-finalists-in-fedexs-small-business-competition.html |title= Beaufort’s NanoandMore USA One of Three National Finalists in FedEx’s Small Business Competition |author= |date= |work= |publisher= http://www.savannahbusinessjournal.com |accessdate=17 January 2012}} - serving the North and South America markets. == Products == [[AFM probe]]s and accessories distributed by NanoAndMore are used for [[Atomic Force Microscopy]] in [[material science]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Martin | first1 = P. | last2 = Marsaudon | first2 = S. | last3 = Aimé | first3 = J. P. | last4 = Bennetau | first4 = B. | title = Experimental determination of conservative and dissipative parts in the tapping mode on a grafted layer: Comparison with frequency modulation data | journal = Nanotechnology | volume = 16 | issue = 6 | pages = 901 | year = 2005 | doi = 10.1088/0957-4484/16/6/046}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Taubert | first1 = A. | last2 = Arbell | first2 = I. | last3 = Mecke | first3 = A. | last4 = Graf | first4 = P. | title = Photoreduction of a crystalline Au(III) complex: A solidstate approach to metallic nanostructures | journal = Gold Bulletin | volume = 39 | issue = 4 | pages = 205 | year = 2006 | doi = 10.1007/BF03215555}}{{Cite journal | last1 = Toset | first1 = J. | last2 = Gomila | first2 = G. | title = Three-dimensional manipulation of gold nanoparticles with electro-enhanced capillary forces | journal = Applied Physics Letters | volume = 96 | issue = 4 | pages = 043117 | year = 2010 | doi = 10.1063/1.3297903|bibcode = 2010ApPhL..96d3117T }} [[physics]],{{Cite journal | last1 = Hoogenboom | first1 = B. [[AFM probe]]s sold by NanoAndMore fit all common [[Atomic Force Microscope|Atomic Force Microscopes (AFM)]] like Asylum Research, [[Bruker]], JPK, Molecular Imaging, [[Nanosurf]], [[Veeco]], WiTEK, NTMDT, Novascan, etc. As an important distributor of [[AFM probe]]s it is often cited as supplier in research papers and is therefore considered an important source for products for [[Atomic Force Microscopy]].{{cite web |url= http://www.hessen-nanotech.de/mm/03_Unternehmen_N-Z.pdf |title= Nanotechnologie Unternehmen - NanoAndMore GmbH |author= www.hessen-nanotech.de |page= 102 |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=17 January 2012}}{{cite web |url= http://www.nanoproducts.de/index.php?mp=products&file=info&manufacturers_id=139&products_id=483 |title= Katalog - NanoAndMore GmbH - AFM sensoren |author= www.nanoproducts.de |date= |work= |publisher= |accessdate=17 January 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Nanotechnology companies]] [[Category:Technology companies of Germany]]

revision.text:
A '''nanoruler''' is a ruler of tiny proportions, made of a [[silicon]] [[crystal structure|crystal lattice structure]]. Since it can accurately measure fractions of [[nanometers]], it could help standardize the future [[nanotechnology]] industry. Since the characteristics of silicon are well understood, the distance between one crystal lattice line to another is well known. Therefore, counting these lines can reveal a fairly accurate measurement.
The ruler was developed by the [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]], and unveiled in 2005.
'''Nanoruler''' also is the name of a machine to produce large (greater than 300 mm x 300 mm) grating patterns with nanometer precision, based on the principle of Scanning Beam Interference Lithography. Instead of the traditional technique to produce gratings through mechanical ruling, this approach rules gratings through the interference of light beams. The Nanoruler was developed in the [[Space Nanotechnology Laboratory]] of the Kavli Institute for Astrophysics and Space Research at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]].
== Sources ==
*http://www.newscientist.com/article.ns?id=dn7068 *http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2004/nanoruler-0128.html
[[Category:Nanotechnology]]

{{short description|A device which removes nitrogen from air}} {{Missing information | non-PSA oxygen generators|date=October 2013}}
An '''oxygen concentrator''' is a [[machine|device]] that concentrates the [[oxygen]] from a gas supply (typically ambient air) by selectively removing nitrogen to supply an oxygen-enriched product gas stream.
Two methods in common use are [[pressure swing adsorption]] and [[membrane gas separation]].
== History == Home medical oxygen concentrators were invented in the early 1970s. Manufacturing output of these devices increased in the late 1970s. [[Union Carbide]] Corporation (UCC) and [[Bendix Corporation]] were both early manufacturers. Prior to that era, home medical oxygen therapy required the use of heavy high pressure oxygen cylinders or small cryogenic liquid oxygen systems. Both of these delivery systems required frequent home visits by suppliers to replenish oxygen supplies. In the United States Medicare switched from fee-for-service payment to a flat monthly rate for home oxygen therapy in the mid-1980s, causing the durable medical equipment (DME) industry to rapidly embrace concentrators as a way to control costs. This reimbursement change dramatically decreased the number of primary high pressure and liquid oxygen delivery systems in use in homes in the United States at that time. Oxygen concentrators became the preferred and most common means of delivering home oxygen. The number of manufacturers entering the oxygen concentrator market increased exponentially as a result of this change. [[Union Carbide]] Corporation (UCC) invented [[molecular sieve]] in the 1950s which made these devices possible. UCC also invented the first cryogenic liquid home medical oxygen systems in the 1960s.
== How oxygen concentrators work == {{Refimprove section|date=October 2013}} {{further|Pressure swing adsorption}} Oxygen concentrators typically use [[pressure swing adsorption]] (PSA) technology and are used very widely for oxygen provision in healthcare applications, especially where liquid or pressurized oxygen is too dangerous or inconvenient, such as in homes or in portable clinics. For other purposes there are also concentrators based on [[Nitrogen separation membrane|membrane technology]].
An oxygen concentrator takes in air and removes nitrogen from it, leaving an oxygen enriched gas for use by people requiring medical oxygen due to low oxygen levels in their blood.<ref>[http://www.medequip.co.in/what-oxygen-concentrator-how-work-oxygen-concentrator/ What is an Oxygen Concentrator? How does it Work?]. medequip.co.in Retrieved on 5 January 2018.</ref> Oxygen concentrators are also used to provide an economical source of oxygen in industrial processes, where they are also known as oxygen gas generators or [[Oxygen plant|oxygen generation plants]]. Oxygen concentrators utilize a [[molecular sieve]] to adsorb gases and operate on the principle of [[Pressure swing adsorption#Rapid PSA|rapid pressure swing adsorption]] of atmospheric [[nitrogen]] onto [[zeolite]] minerals and then venting the nitrogen. This type of adsorption system is therefore functionally a nitrogen scrubber leaving the other atmospheric gases to pass through. This leaves oxygen as the primary gas remaining. PSA technology is a reliable and economical technique for small to mid-scale oxygen generation, with cryogenic separation more suitable at higher volumes and external delivery generally more suitable for small volumes.<ref>{{cite book | isbn = 978-0-471-18818-6 | title = Pressure Swing Adsorption | last1 = Ruthven | first1 = Douglas M. |author2=Shamsuzzman Farooq, Kent S. Knaebel | year = 1993 | publisher = Wiley-VCH | page = 6,304 }}</ref>
At high pressure, the porous zeolite [[adsorption|adsorbs]] large quantities of nitrogen, due to its large surface area and chemical character. After the oxygen and other free components are collected the pressure drops which allows nitrogen to desorb.
An oxygen concentrator has an air compressor, two cylinders filled with zeolite pellets, a pressure equalizing reservoir, and some valves and tubes. In the first half-cycle the first cylinder receives air from the compressor, which lasts about 3 seconds. During that time the pressure in the first cylinder rises from atmospheric to about 2.5 times normal atmospheric pressure (typically 20 psi/138 kPa gauge, or 2.36 atmospheres absolute) and the zeolite becomes saturated with nitrogen. As the first cylinder reaches near pure oxygen (there are small amounts of argon, CO<sub>2</sub>, water vapour, [[radon]] and other minor atmospheric components) in the first half-cycle, a valve opens and the oxygen-enriched gas flows to the pressure equalizing reservoir, which connects to the patient's oxygen hose. At the end of the first half of the cycle, there is another valve position change so that the air from the compressor is directed to the 2nd cylinder. The pressure in the first cylinder drops as the enriched oxygen moves into the reservoir, allowing the nitrogen to be desorbed back into gas. Partway through the second half of the cycle, there is another valve position change to vent the gas in the first cylinder back into the ambient atmosphere, keeping the concentration of oxygen in the pressure equalizing reservoir from falling below about 90%. The pressure in the hose delivering oxygen from the equalizing reservoir is kept steady by a pressure reducing valve.
Older units cycled with a period of about 20 seconds, and supplied up to 5 [[litre]]s per minute of 90+% oxygen. Since about 1999, units capable of supplying up to 10 lpm have been available.
== Applications == [[File:Philips Respironics Oxygen Concentrator. Photo taken by me on April 24th, 2012.jpg|thumb|Philips Respironics Home Oxygen Concentrator.]] PSA generators provide a cost-efficient source of [[oxygen]]. They are a safer,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Duke | first1 = T. | last2 = Wandi | first2 = F. | last3 = Jonathan | first3 = M. | last4 = Matai | first4 = S. | last5 = Kaupa | first5 = M. | last6 = Saavu | first6 = M. | last7 = Subhi | first7 = R. | last8 = Peel | first8 = D. | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(08)61164-2 | title = Improved oxygen systems for childhood pneumonia: A multihospital effectiveness study in Papua New Guinea | journal = The Lancet | volume = 372 | issue = 9646 | pages = 1328–1333 | year = 2008 | pmid = 18708248| pmc = }}</ref> less expensive,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Friesen | first1 = R. M. | last2 = Raber | first2 = M. B. | last3 = Reimer | first3 = D. H. | doi = 10.1007/BF03015531 | title = Oxygen concentrators: A primary oxygen supply source | journal = Canadian Journal of Anesthesia | volume = 46 | issue = 12 | pages = 1185–1190 | year = 1999 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> and more convenient alternative to tanks of cryogenic oxygen or pressurised cylinders. They can be used in various industries including medical, pharmaceutical production, water treatment and glass manufacture.
PSA generators are particularly useful in remote or inaccessible parts of the world or mobile [[medical facilities]] ([[military hospital]]s, disaster facilities).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.co2crc.com.au/RESEARCH/research_c_2_4.html |title=CO2CRC Research – Storing CO2 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130928060025/http://www.co2crc.com.au/RESEARCH/research_c_2_4.html |archivedate=September 28, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Shrestha | first1 = B. M. | last2 = Singh | first2 = B. B. | last3 = Gautam | first3 = M. P. | last4 = Chand | first4 = M. B. | title = The oxygen concentrator is a suitable alternative to oxygen cylinders in Nepal | doi = 10.1007/BF03020412 | journal = Canadian Journal of Anesthesia | volume = 49 | issue = 1 | pages = 8–12 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11782322| pmc = }}</ref>
=== Portable oxygen concentrators === [[File:Home oxygen concentrator.jpg|thumb|right|A home oxygen concentrator in an [[emphysema]] patient's house. The model shown is the DeVILBISS LT 4000.]] {{Main|Portable oxygen concentrator}} Since the early 2000s, a number of companies have produced portable oxygen concentrators.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://oxygenconcentratorratings.com/the-rise-of-portable-concentrator-manufactures/ |title=The Rise of Portable Concentrator Manufacturers |publisher=Oxygen Concentrator Ratings|accessdate=2013-10-12}}</ref> Typically, these devices produce the equivalent of one to five liters per minute of continuous oxygen flow and they use some version of pulse flow or "demand flow" to deliver oxygen only when the patient is inhaling. They can also provide pulses of oxygen either to provide higher intermittent flows or to reduce the power consumption.
Research into oxygen concentration is ongoing and modern techniques suggest that the amount of adsorbent required by a medical oxygen concentrators can be potentially "reduced by a factor of three while offering ∼10–20% higher oxygen recovery compared to a typical commercial unit."<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1002/aic.14518| title = Novel design and performance of a medical oxygen concentrator using a rapid pressure swing adsorption concept| journal = AIChE Journal| pages = 3330–3335| year = 2014| last1 = Rama Rao | first1 = V. | last2 = Kothare | first2 = M. V. | last3 = Sircar | first3 = S. | volume=60| issue = 9}}</ref>
These portable concentrators typically plug into an [[electrical outlet]] and may have an internal battery or external battery pack for operation away from home. Portable oxygen concentrators usually can be plugged into the [[direct current|DC]] outlet of a vehicle, and most of these devices are suitable for ambulatory use.
The [[(FAA) has approved the use of portable oxygen concentrators on commercial airlines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.faa.gov/about/initiatives/cabin_safety/portable_oxygen/ |title=FAA Approved Portable Oxygen Concentrators |publisher=FAA |date= |accessdate=2012-03-09}}</ref> However, users of these devices should check in advance as to whether a particular brand or model is permitted on a particular airline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inogenoxygen.com.au/the-list-of-portable-oxygen-loving-airlines/ |title=List of Airlines that allow portable oxygen machines |publisher=Inogen Oxygen |date= |accessdate=2014-03-26}}</ref> Unlike in commercial airlines, users of aircraft without [[cabin pressurization]] need oxygen concentrators which are able to deliver enough flowrate even at high altitudes, such as OXYFLY.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oxyfly.com/oxyfly-286.html |title=Continuous Oxygen Supply for non-pressurized Aircraft |publisher=OXYFLY |date= |accessdate=2012-06-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120610013906/http://www.oxyfly.com/oxyfly-286.html |archivedate=2012-06-10 |df= }}</ref>
Usually, "demand" or pulse-flow oxygen concentrators are not used by patients while they sleep. There have been problems with the oxygen concentrators not being able to detect when the sleeping patient is inhaling. Some larger portable oxygen concentrators are designed to operate in continuous-flow mode in addition to pulse-flow mode. Continuous-flow mode is considered safe for night use when coupled with a [[Continuous Positive Airway Pressure|CPAP]] machine.
Common models retail at around $600.{{citation needed|date=October 2013}} Leasing arrangements may be available through various medical-supply companies and/or insurance agencies.
=== Alternate applications === Repurposed medical oxygen concentrators or specialized industrial oxygen concentrators can be made to operate ''small'' [[oxyacetylene]] or other fuel gas cutting, welding and [[lampworking]] torches.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.pyronamix.com/page6.html | title = Testimonials | accessdate = 2013-09-18 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070707113925/http://www.pyronamix.com/page6.html | archivedate = July 7, 2007}}</ref>
== Safety == {{Refimprove section|date=October 2013}} In both clinical and emergency-care situations, oxygen concentrators have the advantage of not being as dangerous as [[gas cylinder|oxygen cylinders]], which can, if ruptured or leaking, greatly increase the combustion rate of a fire. As such, oxygen concentrators are particularly advantageous in [[military]] or [[disaster]] situations, where oxygen tanks may be dangerous or unfeasible.
Oxygen concentrators are considered sufficiently foolproof to be supplied to individual patients as a prescription item for use in their homes. Typically they are used as an adjunct to [[positive airway pressure|CPAP]] treatment of severe [[sleep apnea]]. There also are other medical uses for oxygen concentrators, including [[COPD]] and other respiratory diseases.
Used and refurbished units should be purchased through a reputable dealer. Temperamental units are worthless to the medical community since an individual's health frequently relies on the constant extended operation of the unit. However, such units are valuable to metal and glasswork hobbyists. Because oxygen is a "permanent gas" (cannot be liquefied at any pressure at room temperature), it is expensive to obtain in bottled form.
== Industrial oxygen concentrators == {{Refimprove section|date=October 2013}} [[File:PSA OXYGEN GENERATOR R-OXY RIFAIR.JPG|thumb|Pressure swing adsorption medical oxygen generator "R-OXY" by RIFAIR Technical Systems]] Industrial processes may use much higher pressures and flows than medical units. To meet that need, another process, called [[vacuum swing adsorption]] (VSA), has been developed by [[Air Products & Chemicals|Air Products]]. This process uses a single low pressure blower and a valve that reverses the flow through the blower so that the regeneration phase occurs under a vacuum. Generators using this process are being marketed to the [[aquaculture]] industry. Industrial oxygen concentrators are often available in a much wider range of capacities than medical concentrators.
Industrial oxygen concentrators are sometimes referred to as oxygen ''generators'' within the oxygen and ozone industries to distinguish them from medical oxygen ''concentrators''. The distinction is used in an attempt to clarify that industrial oxygen concentrators are not [[medical device]]s approved by the [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) and they are not suitable for use as bedside medical concentrators. However, applying the oxygen generator nomenclature can lead to confusion. The term, oxygen ''generator,'' is a misnomer in that the oxygen is not ''generated'' as it is with a [[chemical oxygen generator]], but rather it is concentrated from the air.
Non-medical oxygen concentrators can be used as a feed gas to a medical oxygen system, such as the oxygen system in a [[hospital]], though governmental approval is required, such as by the FDA, and additional filtering is generally required.
== See also == * {{annotated link|Nitrogen separation membrane}} * {{annotated link|Oxygen therapy}} * {{annotated link|Portable oxygen concentrator}} * {{annotated link|Membrane gas separation}}
